publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

monogr.title: Most approued, and long experienced vvater-vvorkes : Containing, the manner of winter and summer-drowning of medow and pasture, by the aduantage of the least, riuer, brooke, fount, or water-prill adiacent; there-by to make those grounds (especially if they be drye) more fertile ten for one. As also a demonstration of a proiect, for the great benefit of the common-wealth generally, but of Hereford-shire especially. By Rowland Vaughan, Esquire
monogr.author: Vaughan, Rowland

keywords.term: Agriculture, viticulture, texts on hunting, veterinary science

lg.l: THus runnes our Water-workes vnto this end,
That all that worke by them, by them may play▪
For, if they Mossy-grounds by them amend,
For paines and pleasures (then) they'l freely pay.
This WORKE consists not (like some idle Tracts)
No; this is practicall, faire shewes in Acts,
To make the poor'st, the richest Nation.
Then, chiefly aym'd I not at publick-good,
I would not thus divulge my priuate skill:
But, bee'ng free-borne, my Natur's like my Blood;
Which would do good to all, and no man ill:
Then, All (I hope) or of that All, the best
Will wish me well: as for the rest, I rest.

closer.signed: Theirs as they giue me cause, Rowland Vaughan.
